Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Human Robot Interaction System Using Affective Theory-of-Mind Computing to Improve User-Responses and Efficacy of Automated Tutoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advances artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics by developing the foundation for emotionally responsive systems. Building on Theory of Mind research in psychology and robotics, this project focuses on enhancing a robot's capacity to integrate two pieces of information in order to determine a third piece. These inferences can be concrete or as abstract as conjectures about another agent's - including a human user's -beliefs, desires, and intentions. The project creates a framework for the robot's AI system to maintain several competing models of the world (particles) and select and modify those models that have a higher likelihood of matching the real world (filtering). This method of "Particle Filtering" is an effective strategy or navigating complex environments. The core research focuses on adapting and assessing particle filtering methods within abstract contexts including knowledge, emotional, and goal states. If successful, as the robot gains additional information through sensors and language processing, it will adapt its models of the users' emotional state and adjust its interactions accordingly. Essentially, this integrative framework will enable robots to understand human desires and frustrations to find creative solutions in response to those needs.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the evolution of an Artificial Intelligence interface that emulates an empathic human-to-human experience. Because the system will represent and track multiple dimensions about a human user, the robot can recognize when a user is confused or frustrated and respond accordingly. This intuitive, naturalistic AI platform has substantial research, education, and therapeutic applications and commercialization channels. With its open source software infrastructure and the relative low-cost of the platform, the initial commercial targets are as a platform for robust Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education and as therapeutic technology for children and adults on the autism spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The term compassion involves two elements: deep understanding of another’s situation and the desire to respond to needs based on that understanding. For robots to manifest compassion, they require a dynamically updating model both of the observable universe and the hidden state of the humans with which they interact. These hidden states include feelings, unmet needs, goals and aspirations. Technology that allows robots to understand human desires and frustrations and creatively find ways to improve the situation is highly beneficial in diverse applications.

Hanson RoboKind’s Computational Compassion project represents an incremental, but profound step in Artificial Intelligence (AI) to build emotionally responsive systems. Our initial application focus was to develop a system that detects informational and emotive needs while tutoring a human user in a specific subject.  This has been further developed into a focus on autism therapy and training as our initial  target area. Overall, our approach defines a new, reusable framework for defining interactive systems. By defining information and options modularly, we have developed a scalable, dynamically composed system that responds to user’s needs. The elements we defined in this tutoring domain can form the basis for reuse in additional open-source systems.

Hanson RoboKind’s Computational Compassion project represents an incremental, but profound step in AI to build emotionally responsive systems. Specifically, we build probabilistic reasoning methods for human users’ knowledge and emotional states such that the robots can maintain multiple, even competing individual models of the world. By enabling the robots to link multiple small bits of information or “particles,” the systems can build, test, and reform microtheories or models about the world with which they can create larger models about the human user and the broader environment. From this architecture, the robots can respond and adapt to diverse sensory and linguistic inputs from the user, actively selecting and modifying those microtheories that have higher likelihood of matching the real world. The robots’ ability to anticipate and make rapid real-time adjustments will create a radically more humanistic interface. Specifically, they will be able to perceive through language processing and sensors attributes of human users that enable them to build theories about the human’s emotional state.

From these theories, the robots can predict and respond to user’s needs and wants. This architecture also provides a construct through which the robots themselves can begin to build their own models of the world simultaneously independent from, but in concert with, the models of the human users around them.

We have significantly achieved the objective of an operating framework with the creation of the Contextually Interpreted Prolog (CiPro) module as an integrative central blackboard, with multiple knowledge sources. Each logical context can be updated dynamically and can be marked with probability. Responding to inferred user needs is  made possible by including planning software compatible with the microtheory system. Microtheories can be arranged in a network of viewpoints, each able to incorporate background knowledge and contextual information. Planning occurs using the most likely true microtheory and produces a response using sets of microtheories of that describe the currently available options. The CiPro module also provides numerous connections to external services including web services and a web interface.
